conclusion: Analyze the motion of the positively charged ball under electric field and gravity to find the difference in electric potential energy at the highest point compared to point O.
The electric field is directed horizontally to the left.
Electric force on the ball is directed to the left with magnitude F_e = qE.
Gravitational force acts vertically downward with magnitude F_g = mg.
The ball starts at point O with initial velocity v_0 at angle θ to the horizontal.
The ball moves along a straight line at angle θ due to electric and gravitational forces, with vertical velocity component zero at the highest point.
Electric potential energy U of the ball in an electric field is U = qV.
Change in electric potential energy is determined by the work done by the electric force.
Work done by electric force is W_e = qE * d.
Horizontal displacement d is v_0 * cos(θ) * t.
Time to reach the highest point is t = (v_0 * sin(θ)) / g.
Substitute t into d to get d = (v_0^2 * sin(θ) * cos(θ)) / g.
Substitute d into W_e to get W_e = qE * (v_0^2 * sin(θ) * cos(θ)) / g.
Change in electric potential energy ΔU is -W_e = -qE * (v_0^2 * sin(θ) * cos(θ)) / g.
The difference in electric potential energy at the highest point compared to point O is ΔU = -qE * (v_0^2 * sin(θ) * cos(θ)) / g.
